title: Philosophical Prose and Abstract Discourse
description: Grammatical structures for expressing complex philosophical ideas

sections.title: Nominalization in Abstract Discourse
sections.explanation: Turning processes into things to discuss them abstractly.

patterns.process: know → knowledge; perceive → perception; exist → existence
patterns.example: The knowledge of knowledge itself—reflexive epistemology—raises unique difficulties.
patterns.effect: Allows treating processes as objects of analysis

patterns.process: possible → possibility; certain → certainty; true → truth
patterns.example: The very possibility of truth presupposes what it seeks to establish.
The underdetermination of theory by evidence suggests the inevitability of extra-empirical factors in theory choice.

sections.title: Qualified Assertion
sections.explanation: Expressing degrees of commitment to claims in philosophical argument.

gradients.example: One might speculate that this paradox dissolves if...

sections.title: Self-Referential and Metalinguistic Constructions
sections.explanation: Structures for talking about language, concepts, and thought itself.

patterns.example: 'Truth' is a five-letter word. [mention] / Truth is the aim of inquiry. [use]
patterns.note: Quotation marks or italics indicate mention

patterns.example: The concept of freedom presupposes that of constraint.
patterns.note: Explicitly marks conceptual level of analysis

patterns.example: What we call 'knowledge' in everyday discourse may not satisfy philosophical standards.
Language is arbitrary in the sense that signs bear no natural relation to what they signify.

structures.form: X is at once A and not-A
structures.example: The subject is at once constituted by power and resistant to it.

structures.form: Not A but B, where B is revealed A
structures.example: This is not the absence of meaning but meaning as absence.

structures.form: The very X that Y is also what Z
structures.example: The very universality that enables communication is also what constrains it.
structures.function: Shows how same feature produces opposing effects

exercises.original: When we know something, we cannot also doubt it at the same time.
exercises.answer: The simultaneous possession of knowledge and doubt regarding the same object presents a logical impossibility.

exercises.instruction: Reduce the certainty of this claim appropriately
exercises.original: This proves that Descartes was wrong about consciousness.
exercises.answer: This suggests that Descartes's account of consciousness may require significant revision.

exercises.original: Freedom requires constraints. Without rules, we cannot be free.
exercises.answer: Freedom is not the absence of constraint but is constituted through it; the very limits that appear to restrict us are the conditions of our liberation.
